ca.mcgill.ecse211.project

Class Navigation

  • java.lang.Object
    • ca.mcgill.ecse211.project.Navigation

  • public class Navigation
extends java.lang.Object
    This class is primarily responsible for the navigation of the robot to the island from its starting zone, it is also responsible for the navigation of the robot to its starting zone from the island.

      This method also takes as input the angle we wish to turn to, it then turns the robot to our desired angle The difference between this method and turnTo(double angle_RAD) is that turnTo(double angle_RAD) is called from within travelTo(int x,int y), and the current angle of the robot (from the 0-degree axis) used in turnTo(double angle_RAD) is determined in travelTo(int x,int y) before turnTo(double angle_RAD) is called.

      • turnTo_LightLocalizer

        public static void turnTo_LightLocalizer(double angle_RAD)
        This method also takes as input the angle we wish to turn to, it then turns the robot to our desired angle The difference between this method and turnTo(double angle_RAD) is that turnTo(double angle_RAD) is called from within travelTo(int x,int y), and the current angle of the robot (from the 0-degree axis) used in turnTo(double angle_RAD) is determined in travelTo(int x,int y) before turnTo(double angle_RAD) is called.
        Parameters:
        angle_RAD -

        public void completeTravelTo()
        This method is used to complete navigation to a gridpoint once an obstacle is avoided.

      • moveStraightForWithoutStopping

        public static void moveStraightForWithoutStopping(double distance)
        Moves the robot straight for the given distance.
        Parameters:
        distance - in feet (tile sizes), may be negative

      • moveStraightForUsingTachoCount

        public static void moveStraightForUsingTachoCount(double distance)
        Moves the robot straight for the given distance. The difference between this method and moveStraightForWithoutStopping(double distance) is that in this method, the robot continuously checks if an obstacle has been detected, if so, this method is exited, obstacle avoidance is done, and then the robot completes its navigation procedure
        Parameters:
        distance -

      • NavigationToEntranceOfIslandFromStartZone

        public void NavigationToEntranceOfIslandFromStartZone()
        In this method, assuming that the robot has completed ultrasonic localization and is at the appropriate gridpoint -(1,1) if the starting corner was 0 - the robot navigates to the entrance of the tunnel and stops.

      • NavigateXY

        public void NavigateXY()
        In this method, the robot navigates to a given gridpoint, this method is called from within the NavigationToEntranceOfIslandFromStartZone() method. Keep in mind that the robot travels in the x-direction until it reaches the x coordinate of its destination, the robot then travels in the y-direction until it reaches the y coordinate of its destination.

      • CompleteLightLocalization_Direction_X

        public void CompleteLightLocalization_Direction_X()
        In this method,when navigating in the x-direction, the robot performs light localization at appropriate gridpoints. This method is called from within the NavigateXY() method.

      • CompleteLightLocalization_Direction_Y

        public void CompleteLightLocalization_Direction_Y()
        In this method,when navigating in the y-direction, the robot performs light localization at appropriate gridpoints. This method is called from within the NavigateXY() method.

      • turnBy

        public static void turnBy(double angle)
        Turns the robot by a specified angle. Note that this method is different from Navigation.turnTo(). For example, if the robot is facing 90 degrees, calling turnBy(90) will make the robot turn to 180 degrees, but calling Navigation.turnTo(90) should do nothing (since the robot is already at 90 degrees).
        Parameters:
        angle - the angle by which to turn, in degrees

      • convertAngle

        public static int convertAngle(double angle)
        Converts input angle to the total rotation of each wheel needed to rotate the robot by that angle.
        Parameters:
        angle - the input angle
        Returns:
        the wheel rotations necessary to rotate the robot by the angle

      • convertDistance

        public static int convertDistance(double distance)
        Converts input distance to the total rotation of each wheel needed to cover that distance.
        Parameters:
        distance - the input distance
        Returns:
        the wheel rotations necessary to cover the distance

      • NavigateToSearchZone

        public static void NavigateToSearchZone()
        When this method is called, the robot determines the closest corner of the search zone from its current position (Entrance of the island). The robot then determines whether the closest left gridpoint or the closest right gridpoint is near to the closest corner of the search zone. The robot then navigates to the appropriate closest grid point, it then performs light localization. The robot then navigates to the centre of the corner tile of the closest corner of the search zone. Once the robot has reached the centre of the tile, it faces the centre of the search zone. DetermineAppropriateCornerofSearchZone() within the Navigation class is called to determine the closest corner of the search zone from the robots current position. WhichGridPointIsCloser() within the Navigation class is called to determine whether the left closest gridpoint or the right closest grid point is near to the closest corner of the search zone from the current position of the robot. Once the methods DetermineAppropriateCornerofSearchZone() and WhichGridPointIsCloser() are completed, NavigateXY() within the Navigation class should be called to navigate to the appropriate grid point (Keep in mind that NavigateXY() need to be modified to take into account cases where the robot has to navigate to a point on the playing field that is not a grid point, for example (1.5,2.2)). Light_Localization_PartOne() within the LightLocalizer class should then be called to perform light Localization. NavigateXY should then be called again to navigate to the appropriate position in the search zone. CentreOfSearchZone() should then be called to determine the angle the robot should turn to face the centre of the search zone. The robot then turns to this specific angle after which it will be facing the centre of the search zone. ObstacleAvoidance() method in the Object class is called if an obstacle is to be detected ScanSearchZone() method in the Navigation class is then called in which the robot continues the search and rescue process.

      • DetermineAppropriateCornerofSearchZone

        public static Point DetermineAppropriateCornerofSearchZone()
        Determines the x,y coordinates of the closest corner of the search zone from the current position of the robot
        Returns:
        the gridpoint of the closest corner of the search zone from the current position of the robot

      • WhichGridPointIsCloser

        public static void WhichGridPointIsCloser()
        Determines whether the left closest gridpoint or the right closest gridpoint is near to the closest corner of the search zone from the current position of the robot

      • CentreOfSearchZone

        public static double CentreOfSearchZone()
        Determines the angle to turn to (from the 0-degree axis) so that the robot faces the centre of the search zone.
        Returns:
        The angle to turn to (from the 0-degree axis) so that the robot faces the centre of the search zone

      • ScanSearchZone

        public static void ScanSearchZone()
        In this method, the robot scans the search zone from left to right OR right to left. If a single object is detected, the angle at which the object was detected is stored. The robot then approaches the object and detects what it is, if it is NOT a stranded vehicle, the robot goes to the closest corner of the search zone that it has not visited yet. The robot then positions itself appropriately and scans the search zone again and repeats the procedure until a stranded vehicle is detected. If two objects are detected from one corner of the search zone, the robot approaches each object one by one until it detects a stranded vehicle ObjectDifferentiation() method from the Object class is called to determine whether the object is an obstacle or a stranded vehicle If it is a stranded vehicle,RescueStrandedVehicle() method from the Stranded vehicle class is called in which the stranded vehicle is eventually lifted. Once the stranded vehicle is lifted, NavigateToStartingZone() method in the Navigation class is called making the robot navigate back to the its starting zone

      • NavigateToStartingZone

        public static void NavigateToStartingZone()
        In this method, the robot navigates back to the starting Zone from its current position on the island ObstacleAvoidance() method in the Object class is called if an obstacle is to be detected
